prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity: The required sensitivity is set by the aim of detecting 13CH3CN in the disks surrounding our targets. The estimated line intensity, based on previous PdBI and SMA observations of three of our targets (Beltran et al. 2011, A&A, 525, A151; Beltran et al. 2011, A&A, 532, A91; Cesaroni et al. 2011, A&A, 533, A73) and the simulations presented in the scientific justification, is 20 mJy/beam. We need to detect this at the 10sigma level to perform the kinematic analysis. This implies a required rms of 2 mJy/beam in the 0.8 km/s channels. This velocity resolution will be sufficent to resolve and properly map the Keplerian velocity pattern (linewidth ~7km/s). This sensitivity can be achieved in about 50 min on source. With this integration time, continuum sensitivity is not an issue for our sources, as the minimum expected continuum flux density is 7 mJy and the continuum noise will be 0.15 mJy/beam, even with the conservative assumption that the line-free bandwidth is only 100 MHz.
Imaging requirements: We require a dynamic range of ~100 in the continuum and ~150 for the brightest lines. We expect that self-calibration may be possible on the continuum source. The goal of this proposal is to resolve the hot and dense molecular emission around the central protostar. None of the tracers that we have selected is expected to show extended emission. The integration time is set by sensitivity considerations and not by (u,v) coverage requirements.
Correlator setup: The spectra from these hot cores are expected to be extremely rich and the lines are typically broad (several km/s). We thus divided the correlator in several small units with spectral resolution ranging from 0.7 to 1.3 km/s. In particular, we will use different units to cover the following lines (one per unit): CH3CN(12-11) v=0; CH3CN(12-11) v8=1; 13CH3CN(13-12); SiO(5-4); HC3N(24-23) and (26-25); and several transitions of SO, HCOOCH3, CH3OCH3, C2H5CN. All of these lines are known to be disk tracers, apart from SiO which will be used as jet tracer. The continuum will be constructed using the line-free channels in all spectral windows.
Time constraints: None
User defined calibrations: None

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our objective is to establish whether circumstellar disks exist around O-type (proto)stars, and to characterize them. This is crucial because theory predicts that disk-outflow systems can solve the "radiation-pressure problem" and explain the formation of stars up to 140 Mo. In a Cycle 0 proposal, we found 2 Keplerian disks around young B-type stars. The success of our experiment indicates that disk accretion is the formation route of stars up to 20 Mo. We now wish to extend our search to the most massive stars. We have selected the 6 best possible targets based on the luminosity, IR colour, distance, and association with hot-core tracers and outflows. We wish to observe known disk tracers such as CH3CN in the C34-7 configuration in band 6, to attain about 0.2" resolution, sufficient to resolve disks whose size is predicted to be >0.5". We will interpret the data by means of numerical simulations already available to us. We stress that our project will be successful even if no disk should be detected, because we will set a tight upper limit on the disk diameter and prove that disk-mediated accretion in O-type stars is not as effective as in lower-mass stars.
